page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY (1)
page.content: A lonely and unfrequented place this parish was said to be in ancient times containing l000 acres of land on high ground the soil inclined to chalkey and very flinty and so barren. Thus the historian Hasted describes it. Here has stood a lovely Norman church serene in its quiet beauty for 800 years and in the opposite corner a Saxon burial ground near the Horton Kirby border. The family of de Faukehams came over with the Conqueror and adopted the parish name and lived here 800 years until l949.Previous families owning much of the land in old Fadkham were the Malemanynes,Grandisons, Bryans, Poynings, Dyggis,BNotelers and until l830 Bouverie Pusey family but the moeity of the advowson was retained by this family until l929,although on Philip Bouverie Pusey's death most of the land was sold.
